abstract: The phase of a gesture event, such as a magnify, scroll, or pressure change.
overview:
## Discussion

A gesture phase corresponds to a fluid gesture event. As a gesture event occurs, its phase begins with [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] and ends with either [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended] or [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/cancelled]. All the gesture events are sent to the view under the cursor when the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] occurred.

Technically, a gesture scroll event starts with a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] phase and ends with a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended]. However, when the user puts two fingers down on a trackpad, the trackpad issues [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin], followed by [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began], [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/cancelled], or [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended]. The [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin] event phase signals that scrolling is about to begin before the gesture has technically started. A Magic Mouse does not issue [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin] scroll wheel events.

A pressure event (type [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/pressure]) is a fluid gesture. Like the other fluid gesture events, it has a phase that describes the sequence of the pressure gesture stream.

Legacy scroll wheel events (say from a Mighty Mouse) and momentum scroll wheel events both have a phase of [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEventPhase/NSEventPhaseNone]. (Legacy scroll wheel events also have a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/momentumPhase] of [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEventPhase/NSEventPhaseNone].) To learn more about scroll wheel events, see [https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/EventOverview/HandlingTouchEvents/HandlingTouchEvents.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/10000060i-CH13].

See [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct] for possible values.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/phase-swift.property
crawled: 2025-12-02T05:11:11Z
---

# phase

**Instance Property**

The phase of a gesture event, such as a magnify, scroll, or pressure change.

## Declaration

```swift
var phase: NSEvent.Phase { get }
```

## Discussion

A gesture phase corresponds to a fluid gesture event. As a gesture event occurs, its phase begins with [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] and ends with either [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended] or [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/cancelled]. All the gesture events are sent to the view under the cursor when the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] occurred.

Technically, a gesture scroll event starts with a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began] phase and ends with a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended]. However, when the user puts two fingers down on a trackpad, the trackpad issues [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin], followed by [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/began], [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/cancelled], or [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/ended]. The [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin] event phase signals that scrolling is about to begin before the gesture has technically started. A Magic Mouse does not issue [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct/mayBegin] scroll wheel events.

A pressure event (type [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/pressure]) is a fluid gesture. Like the other fluid gesture events, it has a phase that describes the sequence of the pressure gesture stream.

Legacy scroll wheel events (say from a Mighty Mouse) and momentum scroll wheel events both have a phase of [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEventPhase/NSEventPhaseNone]. (Legacy scroll wheel events also have a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/momentumPhase] of [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEventPhase/NSEventPhaseNone].) To learn more about scroll wheel events, see [https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/EventOverview/HandlingTouchEvents/HandlingTouchEvents.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/10000060i-CH13].

See [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/Phase-swift.struct] for possible values.

## Getting gesture and touch information

- **NSEvent.Phase**: Constants that represent the possible phases during an event phase.
- **magnification**: The amount of change to add to a magnification gesture.
- **touches(matching:in:)**: Returns the touch objects associated with the specified phase.
- **allTouches()**: Returns all touch objects associated with the event.
- **touches(for:)**: Returns the touch objects from the event that belong to the specified view.
- **coalescedTouches(for:)**: Returns all of the touch objects associated with the specified main touch.
- **isMouseCoalescingEnabled**: A Boolean value that indicates whether the system coalesces mouse movement events.
- **NSEvent.GestureAxis**: Constants that specify the direction of travel for a gesture.
